sessions.title: Getting More Out of Git
sessions.description: Having trouble groking Git? Not sure what the difference between merging and rebasing is? Wondering what you would ever use a "cherry-pick" for? We'll cover these topics and more in this talk, helping attendees get past Git novice and on their way to Git master. The talk will being with a short overview of git fundamentals, but quickly jump into more advanced concepts. We'll cover branching, commit amending, stashing, cherry-picking, and yes, merging versus rebasing. You might not be a Git guru after one conference session, but you will have a better understanding of how to play nicely with others in the same Git repository and how to fix common (and not so common) issues in Git.
sessions.speaker: Jordan Kasper

sessions.title: Getting Started with Elm Lang
sessions.description: Tired of JavaScript errors and hard to debug code? Interested in writing more functional JavaScript? Then I believe that Elm is the tool you are looking for. Elm helps you write HTML web apps extremely fast all while pushing you towards well-architected code.
sessions.speaker: Tim Whitacre

sessions.title: Rust for Node developers
sessions.description:
Rust is a programming language from Mozilla that combines strong compile-time correctness guarantees with fast performance and it plays nice with ctypes! Come learn how you can call Rust functions from Node.js code and finally say goodbye to hacking C!
There will be a quick intro to Rust, but more an appetizer than anything else; then explanation about how Rust and Node.js can work together, and at the end a few demos to take advantages from Rust in Node.js
sessions.speaker: Giovanny Gongora

sessions.title: Building non trivial things with WebAssembly
sessions.description: We'll learn the history of how WebAssembly came to be, the goals it aims to solve, and get familiar with the existing tool chain for writing apps with WebAssembly.
sessions.speaker: Nick Larsen

sessions.title: Jasmine and Cucumber - a Tasty way to Deliver Better Code Faster
sessions.description:
Behavior Driven Development is a proven way to deliver higher quality code to meet your business’ requirements in less time and you can add it to any agile processes (like Scrum) that does not specify how software should be developed.

In this session we’ll look at two BDD frameworks; Cucumber and Jasmine. Cucumber is a tool that lets you turn user stories into executable specifications that run every time you check in a code change, so you can verify that what you’re delivering meets the business’ acceptance criteria. Jasmine can be used to write lower level specifications that describe the services needed to make the executable specifications pass. You can use it to write unit tests that ensure the code you’ve written behaves the way you expect. 

Using them together leads to some nice results. You only write code needed to meet the user acceptance criteria, your code behaves the way you expect it to, and you can safely refactor your code to improve clarity, simplify its structure, or meet any other metric you deem necessary. This focused development results in highly cohesive, loosely coupled code, which means it’s easier to debug, maintain and enhance. Now isn’t that a tasty treat?
sessions.speaker: Burk Hufnagel

sessions.title: Your Code is Terrible, I Love It!
sessions.description: Nearly all big projects started out as a small codebase, sometimes even as a POC. When trying to quickly prove out functionality and get a lean version of your product to your customer, you're going to write some sh***y code. It's the nature of the profession. This is not a problem until that wee little app of yours grows into a giant beast. Then you're in trouble because it's an unmaintainable nightmare. This talk will show you techniques for how to take your heaping pile and polish it up enough to sell at the gift shop.
sessions.speaker: Patrick Seda

sessions.title: Does the network seem thin up here? Collaborating over mountaintop mesh networks.
sessions.description:
Digital nomads can now work anytime, anywhere—but often with no WiFi. Despite the explosion of feature-rich web apps, offline editors like Microsoft Word remain their tool of choice, leaving them out in the cold when it comes to realtime collaboration.

With the help of Operational Transforms + Conflict-Free Replicated Data Types, peer-to-peer web apps can enable writers, musicians and other creators to collaborate off-the-grid and climb up to the writer’s ultimate dream: collaborative writing atop Half Dome.

Oh, and we won’t need conference WiFi.
sessions.speaker: Jonathan Martin

sessions.title: Applesoft BASIC Flashback
sessions.description: Applesoft BASIC was the first programming language for many developers who grew up in the 1980s. We'll look back on this language as adults to see how it shaped our learning as developers.
sessions.speaker: Corinna Cohn

sessions.title: aqueduct: A server-side framework in Dart
sessions.description: A look at the Dart programming language and its new server-side framework, aqueduct. This talk will introduce the fundamentals of the Dart programming language and the tools and knowledge necessary to immediately get started building web server applications in aqueduct.
sessions.speaker: Joe Conway

sessions.title: Javascript Software Craftsmanship Part 1
sessions.description: Becoming an expert coder involves much more than learning the coolest new framework or becoming a design pattern ninja.  Becoming an expert coder is about passion and craftsmanship. In this two-part series we will dive into Software Craftsmanship, what it is and how it has not only influenced but also refactored our industry and trade. We wont stop there, we will discuss how to grow beyond being a commodity coder to being mentored and mentoring others, who the mentors are, and how to take ownership of your coding career.  Finally we will look at what often makes JS code suk and the often ignored but essential disciplines of master software craftsmen and how these apply to JS coders.
sessions.speaker: Stephen M. Carlson

sessions.title: Javascript Software Craftsmanship Part 2
sessions.description: Becoming an expert coder involves much more than learning the coolest new framework or becoming a design pattern ninja.  Becoming an expert coder is about passion and craftsmanship. In this two-part series we will dive into Software Craftsmanship, what it is and how it has not only influenced but also refactored our industry and trade. We wont stop there, we will discuss how to grow beyond being a commodity coder to being mentored and mentoring others, who the mentors are, and how to take ownership of your coding career.  Finally we will look at what often makes JS code suk and the often ignored but essential disciplines of master sotware craftsmen and how these apply to JS coders.
sessions.speaker: Stephen M. Carlson

sessions.title: Engaging Engineering Teams in Design
sessions.description: Frequently, designers and engineers tend to run in their own circles and speak their own distinct languages. Interactions between the 2 teams tend to follow a prescribed, limited path: design creates mocks for a planned UI change, engineering implements the mocks and deploys the new UI to the customer. But experience has shown that keeping design and engineering engaged throughout the product development cycle leads to far more coherent, impactful result. Josh Teague (lead designer at FullStory) and Stephanie Brubaker (senior engineer at FullStory) will be sharing lessons from their own experience on how design and engineering teams can work together to create breakthrough products.
sessions.speaker: Josh Teague

sessions.title: ImprovUX
sessions.description: ImprovUX: A talk that brings the worlds of Improvisation and User Experience together...accept they're actually part of the same world with the same ideas and philosophies.
sessions.speaker: Mike Gorgone

sessions.title: UX patterns for developers
sessions.description:
Are you willing to go the extra mile to make your UX shiny and joyful?
Most of us developers underestimate the importance of the Human-Computer Interaction.

Join this talk for developer-friendly UX patterns that you can start using in your everyday code.
sessions.speaker: Jad Joubran

sessions.title: Bridging the designer-developer gap
sessions.description:
It’s no surprise that designers and developers tend to be separate teams. Designers are all about creativity and art; developers are about logic and effectiveness. Yet what we don’t realize is that both of them have one trait in common: to solve problems. Both have to work together to make their product work.
Learn how to better communicate with developers through tips and tricks to help you see things from a developer’s perspective, for less headaches & smarter designs.
sessions.speaker: Nicole Saidy

sessions.title: Let's Get Animated!
sessions.description: Add excitement and user interaction with client-side SVG animations! Get the low-down and make your own SVG animation through this lecture. You'll walk out with confidence towards implementing web animations in your future projects!
sessions.speaker: Tamil Periasamy

sessions.title: ExD: Designing for Exponential Change
sessions.description: An exploration of basic Design Principles and the forcing functions of Exponential Growth, Miniaturization and Dematerialization. Application of these concepts will be demonstrated using a custom set of "Method Cards" that can be sorted and discussed to inform and inspire research and design.
sessions.speaker: Will Jayroe

sessions.title: A Dad’s Eye View of the Coming Infopocalyse
sessions.description: Technology is ruining the youth of today... and it’s going to be awesome. My 5yr old son lives in a world where all media is on-demand, all screens are touch screens, and most of his physical toys have embedded software. He plays with devices differently than I did and expects more from them. This talk will provide a glimpse of the future and how to design experiences for the next generation.
sessions.speaker: Josh Marinacci

sessions.title: Creating a Mobile UX Strategy
sessions.description: Of businesses that have mobile solutions, 44% report the solution wasn’t adopted due to poor user experience. Mobile UX is fundamentally different than web. It’s crucial to think through every factor including platform, content, implementation, performance and goals. By understanding the role that UX plays in a mobile strategy you can prevent low adoption rates and instead create a successful project.
sessions.speaker: Grant Davies

sessions.title: Tablets and Hybrids Need Mobile-Optimized Websites, Too!
sessions.description: It takes extra work to deliver a truly responsive website. Since larger tablets and hybrids such as iPad Pros and Windows Surface devices can fit the full size of a standard laptop/desktop website, a tempting thought is to save time and deliver to them the exact same experience. This talk may change your mind, elaborating on why that kind of thinking can hamper the user experience and possibly drive people away, perhaps to access your website on a laptop or smartphone, or worse yet to a competitor.
sessions.speaker: Andrew Malek

sessions.title: Make Web Forms Great Again
sessions.description: Has your web form conversion rate hit a wall? Are users skipping filling out your long forms, not receiving confirmation e-mails, or getting pestered with password or data format warnings *after* they finish entering their information? If so, then it's time to #MakeWebFormsGreatAgain. Learn suggestions of A/B tests you can try with your web forms to help encourage more people to interact.
sessions.speaker: Andrew Malek

sessions.title: Introduction to Aurelia
sessions.description: Aurelia is a next generation JavaScript client framework for mobile, desktop and web. It's the most standards-compliant, highly performing and simplest technology of its kind today. In this course you'll have an opportunity to learn directly from Aurelia's architect and project lead, Rob Eisenberg. He'll teach you how to create modern web applications using an MVVM approach with Aurelia. You also will learn how to extend HTML with custom elements and attributes, how to handle client-side routing and even cover best practices in project organization, maintenance and deployment.
sessions.speaker: Rob Eisenberg

sessions.title: Composition vs. inheritance
sessions.description: A look at the benefits of functional composition and factory functions vs. traditional inheritance.
sessions.speaker: Dylan Schiemann

sessions.title: JavaScript Objects Deep Dive
sessions.description: Bob, our tour guide, will take us on a unique visual tour of JavaScript objects. We'll explore where the community has been and where it is going with a visual approach to creating and relating objects, prototype chains, inheritance, composition, and all that fun stuff.
sessions.speaker: Bob Holben

sessions.title: Web Components & Polymer: Lego bricks of the web
sessions.description: Writing the same login form over and over again? Web components offer a modular approach to creating reusable UI widgets. Ditch large, complex frameworks and drop these lightweight building blocks into your site. We will show you how to build, test, and deploy a web component, and introduce you to the wide selection of existing web components available through Google’s Polymer.
sessions.speaker: Pearl Latteier

sessions.title: Webpack: A Simple Introduction to a Complex Tool
sessions.speaker: John Mercer

sessions.title: Wed, Bed, or Dead ( or how to pick the tech stack for your next project)
sessions.description: Everyone wants to be the cool kid using the tools and frameworks that all of the cool kids are using.  But, is the frame work the right choice for your project? Does it scale? Is it flexible? Maintainable? Is it for right now (bed)? Or if you use (wed) it, how difficult is it to switch to something else? Go through the process of evaluating libraries and frameworks to decide if and how they would fit into the architecture of your next project.
sessions.speaker: Delicia Brummitt

sessions.title: Oh Composable World!
sessions.description: The biggest sources of code complexity are state & control flow. Loops, conditionals, try/catch blocks, callbacks, & mutable variable assignment is one way to ensure such complexity. By contrast, if we have a composable set of pieces that plug together, we can “dot chain” a single expression for which our data flows through. We’ll examine techniques from functional programming, borrow some moves from OO, and write blocks of dead-simple to understand code.
sessions.speaker: Brian Lonsdorf

sessions.title: Prototype to Production - Ember to the Rescue
sessions.description: Looking at the expanse of developing a new product there are hundreds of small mechanisms that need to be in place as you take an idea from prototype to production.  This talk is a look at using Ember to race up the canyon walls to the plateau of maintaining a production application.  Aside from developing a maintainable, useful, and working application, the development team will need to think about the following: build systems and deployment, wireframes to components, simultaneous API and client development, feature spikes with 3rd party libraries, and post-launch maintenance and education.  While examining two start-up projects, I will explore these topics and how Ember helps to provide streamlined solutions.
sessions.speaker: Todd Gandee

sessions.title: Creating Kickass Data Visualizations with D3
sessions.description: Tired of boring charts that all look the same or only have a few configurations? Join me in a D3js jumpstart session to learn the core concepts of D3. The goal is to show D3 capabilities, core concepts, and gotchas, so you can start building kickass data visualizations. Set yourself free by learning how D3js can provide all the tools needed to visualize data on the web.
sessions.speaker: Chris Morrow

sessions.title: JavaScript error reporting and why we can't have nice things
sessions.description: Wouldn't it be nice if, instead of relying on users to report bugs, your web app automatically did it for you? In this talk, learn how to collect JS errors from your web apps – how to do it, why it's hard, and why you should consider 3rd-party libraries and tools to do it for you.
sessions.speaker: Ben Vinegar

sessions.title: Testing ES6 and TypeScript apps with Intern
sessions.description: Learn how to test all the things with your modern ES6 and/or TypeScript applications using Intern.
sessions.speaker: Dylan Schiemann

sessions.title: Building a progressive web app with Angular 2
sessions.description:
Progressive web apps can give your website a native like user experience.
Angular 2 makes it easier than ever to build progressive web apps with its new mobile toolkit.
Learn how to get started and build your own PWA using Angular 2!
sessions.speaker: Jad Joubran

sessions.title: Scaling large Angular 1 apps
sessions.description:
Although Angular JS is a powerful framework, we still need conventions, automation and a variety of tools to make it scale. Especially in a team environment. Learn how to scale your angular apps with simple but effective techniques, endorsed by the Angular community.

There are so many Angular 1 apps out there that won't be upgraded to Angular 2... but they still need to be updated with new features & be able to serve a lot of users.
sessions.speaker: Jad Joubran

sessions.title: Preparing Angular 1.x apps to upgrade to Angular 2
sessions.description:
Preparing Applications to Upgrade to Angular 2
Refactoring Angular 1.5
sessions.speaker: John Mercer

sessions.title: Building a Secure Chat App with AngularJS and Ionic
sessions.description: A basic chat app in AngularJS is pretty easy.  It can be done in about 50 lines of code plus a simple NodeJS backend to repeat messages. Making a good and complete chat app, however, is far more difficult.  This talk will cover building a chat app from beginning to end, including scroll back history, offline notifications, authentication, security, and packaging for publishing in mobile app stores.
sessions.speaker: Josh Marinacci

sessions.title: Introduction to Angular2
sessions.description: AngularJS is the incredibly popular framework for building single-page web applications. Version 2.0 is a major leap from the 1.x version designed to address shortcomings in the original 5+ year old framework and to embrace modern browsers and language features. It is being written using TypeScript, a superset of JavaScript that allows you to build code using next generation features and compile it to JavaScript that will run on current browsers
sessions.speaker: Jeremy Likness

sessions.title: Refactoring AngularJS Applications
sessions.description: AngularJS applications are often rushed into production with little consideration for long term support or maintainability. This session will discuss strategies for refactoring Angular 1.x applications to make them easier to support over the application's service life.
sessions.speaker: Corinna Cohn

sessions.title: Angular Performance Pitfalls
sessions.description: Performance and memory can quickly get away from you in JavaScript, and some features in Angular 1 can exacerbate the problem. We will discuss some basic causes for performance drains and memory leaks in JavaScript and some specific misuses of Angular that run into them.
sessions.speaker: K. Devin McIntyre

sessions.title: Angular Architectures: A roadmap for the hearty traveller
sessions.description:
There is no doubt that Angular is now mainstream. That made it easier for you to convince the powers-that-be to let you select Angular for your project. You've done a small but successful POC and now your 'big' project has been green lighted to kick off next month. Your team is jazzed but as you start to plan out the real work, you begin to realize that there are many aspects inherrent to large Angular projects that have no 'out of the box' answers.

Stack overflow can only contribute 'it depends' answers that leave you more confused than before you read them. And now the panic starts to seep in, killing your buzz. Never fear! In this session, we will explore a variety of ways to architect your project and structure your code. We will look at the pros and cons of each option and discuss when trigger points for choosing each.
sessions.speaker: Peter Pavlovich

sessions.title: Forming an opinion about Angular Forms in 1.X and 2.0
sessions.description: Forming an opinion about Angular Forms in 1.X and 2.0
sessions.speaker: Peter Pavlovich

sessions.title: Angular 2 Toolset Support
sessions.description: This talk is about the design decisions that make Angular easy for static code analysis, and some of the tools that can help your Angular code be less error-prone and follow a common style.
sessions.speaker: Minko Gechev

sessions.title: Things I learned from Angular 2's Source
sessions.description:
Angular 2 is one of the most discussed technologies during the past year. There are plenty of rumors about the rocket science powering the framework and its exceptional scalability, portability and speed.

A lot of features make Angular unique - runtime generation of VM friendly code that takes advantage of inline-caching, cross-platform portability, facades which allows the same code to be transformed to both Dart and TypeScript, tree-shakable architecture, etc.

Although all this sounds curious, it is hard to explore each individual concept by taking a deep dive at the Angular's codebase which exceeds 100k lines of code. In this talk I will synthesize some of the most interesting things that I discovered during my contribution to the project and involvement in the Angular community.
sessions.speaker: Minko Gechev

sessions.title: Diving into Swift for iOS
sessions.description: A great intro for those looking to start their journey developing IOS apps using Swift. Using the latest version of Swift we will cover the basics of developing IOS apps.
sessions.speaker: Shawn Johnson

sessions.title: Optimizing app install and user on boarding costs
sessions.description: While there are many effective mobile app advertising platforms, understanding which networks are most effective an on boarding new users requires measurement.  Patrick will describe best practices for app conversion tracking and measurement with specific examples from previous apps he has worked on.
sessions.speaker: Patrick Childers

sessions.title: Using MVVM on iOS Effectively
sessions.description:
If you’ve built an iOS app, you know about the MVC pattern, and where UIViewController fits into it. View controllers have become the workhorses of CocoaTouch, and are all too easy to over-burden.

The increasingly popular Model View ViewModel pattern is all about giving view controllers a break, and separating presentation logic from UI. The advent of watchOS and tvOS has made this a great time to learn how and why this is more important than ever.

Through the lens of real-world problems and solutions, we’ll break MVVM down into some simple but effective architectural decisions that can help you keep the ever-blurring lines of the MVC pattern just a little clearer. No dependencies or frameworks, just good patterns and strong architecture.
sessions.speaker: Bradford Dillon

sessions.title: What the Swiftly Func?
sessions.description: Functional programming is all the rage, but what is it exactly.  Without resorting to confusing terms like 'Monad' and 'Functor', this talk seeks to shed a little light on this Important yet confusing approach to programming.
sessions.speaker: James Majors

sessions.title: Confusion Optional
sessions.description: Optional can be confusing, with '?' and '!'.  What does it all mean?  This talk will help you understand the whys and how's of using this important type in Swift
sessions.speaker: James Majors

sessions.title: Enhancing Your Workflow with Xcode Source Editor Extensions
sessions.description: Developers are constantly refining their workflow in order to master their craft. There is a plethora of tools available that can help bootstrap a project, increase efficiency, or simply make developers happy. Let’s explore the newly introduced Xcode Source Editor Extensions; an Application Extension that gives developers the power to create custom actions in Xcode’s Editor menu.
sessions.speaker: Jesse Black

sessions.title: Level Up Your Game With TravisCI: From Zero To Hero In 45 Minutes
sessions.description: TravisCI, Xcode Bots, Fastlane, TestFlight, HockeyApp are only a few of the many tools that are available and highly used to optimize workflows and improve your product. But where do you start? "Level Up Your Game With TravisCI: From Zero To Hero In 45 Minutes" helps you jump start into CI with your iOS projects. No matter if you have never heard about CI before or if you only want to refine your tools.
sessions.speaker: Florian Harr

sessions.title: Creating Connections with Core Location and Map Kit
sessions.description: We live in a world in which technology keeps us closely linked us to our surroundings. Using location-based information in your iOS applications can greatly enhance the user experience, but it’s important to know how to use Core Location and Map Kit correctly in order to optimize accuracy without consuming too much power. In this talk, we’ll take a tour of these frameworks with code samples to demonstrate functionality like indoor positioning, visit monitoring, geofencing, and iBeacons. We’ll also discuss user privacy and authorization for location usage.
sessions.speaker: Marlene Jaeckel

sessions.title: Swift Memory Management
sessions.description: Memory management in Swift is fairly abstracted away from you as a developer and it’s easy to build iOS apps without an understanding of it… until something goes wrong.  This can result in unexpected behavior, unclear error messages, lost data and crashes.  Even a basic understanding of memory management can go a long way, making it easy to prevent these issues in the first place, understand what when wrong when they do occur and know how fix them.
sessions.speaker: Marcus Smith

sessions.title: Session: iOS in the Enterprise
sessions.description: The enterprise environment is different than a commercial or consumer facing development effort. In this intermediate level workshop workshop, we'll cover these topics and take a deep dive into the challenges facing enterprise app developers: Monitoring the app in the field, Enterprise UX concerns, Privacy concerns, APIs and capabilities you'll only use in the enterprise, Enterprise deployment walled garden, Advanced problem solving for application design and performance
sessions.speaker: Carol Shepherd

sessions.title: Building distributed systems with Redux
sessions.description: Redux is a implementation of the FLUX architecture. Actions are dispatched to cause side effects within your application. Actions are plain JSON, and easily serializable. In this talk we will experiment with Redux as elegant solutions to distributed systems.
sessions.speaker: Clint Ayres

sessions.title: Creating more efficient React views using windowing techniques
sessions.description: Learn how to speed your React views up by only rendering what the user wants to see. This technique (commonly referred to as "windowing") is easy to integrate into existing views and can provide huge performance gains.
sessions.speaker: Brian Vaughn

sessions.title: Extending React.Component for Fun and Profit
sessions.description: React Mixins are going away. Higher-order Components can be confusing to beginners. Is there a better way? Learn this one weird trick that functional programmers don't want you to know!
sessions.speaker: Tim Dorr

sessions.title: Sane React Testing
sessions.description: In this talk, you'll learn about the three main inputs to React components that you commonly need to deal with when unit testing and how to properly isolate these concerns in your unit tests. You'll walk away with what you need to know to build a solid, maintainable test suit for your React applications and libraries.
sessions.speaker: Kent C. Dodds

sessions.title: Navigating the React Ecosystem
sessions.description: Let’s walk through the tools that surround React and learn which you should prioritize learning first.
sessions.speaker: Ben Ilegbodu

sessions.title: Re-energize Your Workflow with React and Redux
sessions.description: Redux helps you build applications with React by making it easier to manage data changes and state in your application. In this talk, Jonathan walks you through building applications with React and Redux using ES6, Babel and Webpack.
sessions.speaker: Jonathan Kemp

sessions.title: Pure Functions: An Introduction to Functional Programming in JavaScript
sessions.description: Pure functions are the foundation of functional programming. Using pure functions can make application development in JavaScript easier. But what is a pure function? In this session, you'll learn what pure functions are and how you can use them to simplify your development process. In addition, we'll look at using pure functions to build applications in JavaScript with React and Redux.
sessions.speaker: Jonathan Kemp

sessions.title: Introduction to React.JS
sessions.description: React.js is a view library from Facebook for building performant user-interfaces in JavaScript. In this session, we'll explore React.js and understand why it's a great step forward for building complex UI's that run fast. We'll code up an example web application using React.js and step through the basics of using the library while discussing concepts like the virtual DOM and components.
sessions.speaker: Andrew Smith

sessions.title: Isomorphic React w/o Node??
sessions.description: React is a JavaScript UI library with components that can render server-side for improved SEO and initial browser load time. But how do you render JavaScript React components on the server if your backend doesn’t run on Node? Learn how Eventbrite successfully integrated React with their Python/Django backend so that you can do the same in yours.
sessions.speaker: Ben Ilegbodu

sessions.title: React Router 4.0: What's New
sessions.description: React Router 4.0 brings some big changes to the most popular routing library in the React ecosystem. Come see what's new and all the improvements in this latest API overhaul.
sessions.speaker: Tim Dorr

sessions.title: Deploying GraphQL in a Serverless Architecture
sessions.description: GraphQL's flexibility has made it an intriguing and necesary choice for frontend developers. These developers seem to understand the benefits of using GraphQL before their backend counterparts, but have a hard time selling the benefits in a way that causes the backend team to grasp. Most concerns from backend developers are around the GraphQL structure, reimplemenation of existing logic and deployment. What if you could deploy GraphQL without the need to deploy and manage entire servers? In this talk we'll explore using GraphQL in a serverless context with AWS Lambda, using the Serverless framework. We'll look at the pros and cons of deploying GraphQL in such an architecture.
sessions.speaker: Kevin Old

sessions.title: PSR-7 and Action-Domain-Responder
sessions.description: In this talk, we will discuss PSR-7 (the "HTTP Messages" recommendation) and how it can be used with the Action-Domain-Responder pattern, particularly when it comes to middleware-based systems. We will also go over some PSR-7/ADR libraries and frameworks, such as Relay, Arbiter, and Radar, and address opinions on the separation of concerns between HTTP user interfaces and the underlying application domain.
sessions.speaker: Paul M. Jones

sessions.title: Pulling Up Your Legacy App by its Bootstraps
sessions.description: Your mission, should you choose to accept it, is to support an application built on an older framework. Refactoring isn't an easy option. The code is untested and nowhere near best practices or standards. In this session, we'll talk about strategies to incorporate modern PHP coding practices to add features and functionality and retiring the older code in pieces. We'll review specific examples and code from a real project where we bootstrapped a legacy application that needed a lot of help to become useful to its users and simpler for developers to maintain. We'll talk about strategies to leave the existing code in place until the new code is ready to replace it in whole or in pieces.
sessions.speaker: Emily Stamey

sessions.title: Contract Driven Development
sessions.description: Have you ever used a web-based API that was poorly designed and inconsistent?  Have you found gaps between the documentation and implementation?  At Patientco, we have successfully implemented a Contract Driven Design methodology for APIs.  Swagger is used to design RESTful endpoints before a line of code is written and the specification, documentation, and code are kept in sync through automated testing and deployment.
sessions.speaker: Chris Church

sessions.title: Easy Local Development for PHP or WordPress
sessions.description: If you program in PHP but do not yet develop LOCALLY on your laptop, especially if you develop WordPress-based websites, then this workshop if for you.
sessions.speaker: Mike Schinkel

sessions.title: Iterators, ArrayAccess & Countable – Oh My!
sessions.description: Learn how to empower your objects in PHP with SPL! The SPL (Standard PHP Library) has existed for many years but is still one of the less understood parts of the language. We will cover some of the most useful core aspects of the SPL, features that are easy to add to your own objects, making them more powerful and flexible!
sessions.speaker: Eli White

sessions.title: Aphorisms of API Design
sessions.description: How can we build code that's intended to last and stay robust in the face of change?  What matters are your APIs.  Let's see how to build good, solid code.
sessions.speaker: Larry Garfield

sessions.title: API Security: Slowing down the hackers
sessions.description: APIs are the backbone of modern web applications. Whether they be used as a access point for AJAX queries, mobile apps, 3rd party integrations or just general data feeds, your applications’ API often needs the ability to access everything. Securing the API consequently is essential to the security of your application. This talk will cover the various types of APIs common in web applications, the security issues relevant with the various API types and methods for securing your APIs, and slowing down the hackers.
sessions.speaker: Anthony Green

sessions.title: Developing Bots for Slack
sessions.description: Slack has become incredibly popular, and it provides a new way for developers to build applications, and services. There is a lot of interest in creating for this platform, but there's more to it than just code. The whole process from research, to publishing and distribution will be covered in this session.
sessions.speaker: Nic

sessions.title: PHP 7: The New New PHP
sessions.description: PHP 7: Why aren't you using it yet?  Here's an hour of awesome, brought to you by PHP 7.
sessions.speaker: Larry Garfield

sessions.title: PHP OOP: An Object Oriented Programming Primer
sessions.description: Whether you are a brand new developer or an experienced coder - the PHP object model can hold some mysteries that are worth exploring.  This session will briefly cover the basics of working with Objects in PHP, then dive quickly through inheritance, abstracts, interfaces, traits, late static binding, magic methods, namespaces and maybe even reflection.  It’s a lot to cover to make sure to show up with your eyes open and ready to move quickly!
sessions.speaker: Eli White

sessions.title: Action-Domain-Responder: MVC for the Web
sessions.description: Using Model-View-Controller as a pattern to describe stateless HTTP interactions has always been a bit of a kludge. There simply hasn't been a better pattern web applications -- until now.  ADR (Action-Domain-Responder) represents a refinement of generic MVC as an application architecture specifically tuned to the web. In this talk, we will discuss various patterns of overall application architecture, including MVC, MVP, PAC, DCI, RMR, and others. We will find out how the ADR pattern arises from generic MVC, and how it provides a better description of how web applications actually work. Finally, we will go over examples of how to architect an ADR application, as well as how to convert from an MVC architecture to an ADR one.
sessions.speaker: Paul M. Jones

sessions.title: Ignite Your App Development With NativeScript and Firebase
sessions.description: You've heard about the great enhancements to Firebase, as announced at Google.io, and you're curious about how to leverage them in a mobile app? This session will reveal how you can use NativeScript with Angular 2 to build a cross-platform mobile app that can be updated in realtime. Set your mobile development on fire with Firebase and NativeScript!
sessions.speaker: Jen Looper

sessions.title: HOLD FOR EDWIN
sessions.description: HOLD FOR EDWIN
sessions.speaker: Edwin Huertas

sessions.title: Ionic 2: A new way to do mobile
sessions.description: Ionic has revolutionized the way web developers make the transition mobile development, but there’s always room to improve and make the lives of new app developers easier. With Ionic 2, we’ve improved upon much of what made Ionic 1 great, while also keeping things simple and reducing the fatigue that developers can feel when learning a new tool.
sessions.speaker: Mike Hartington

sessions.title: Cross-Cross Platform
sessions.description: You can utilize Xamarin to write cross platform applications, but did you know the real win can be when you can use it across all platforms - mobile and web?
sessions.speaker: James Prolizo

sessions.title: Creating Interactive Multiplayer Experiences with Firebase
sessions.description:
Building realtime features that work on all your different devices is the holy grail of app development. The Firebase Realtime Database lets you store and sync data instantly, and allows you to build a web, mobile or Unity application in minutes without worrying about wiring up a backend. The real time aspect and a number of lesser known, powerful features (such as transactions) make it possible to create a multiplayer gaming experience as well.

In this session, we'll twist the traditional rock-paper-scissors into a web based, multiplayer  happy-surprised-angry game using your facial expressions and a web-cam. We’ll use both old and new Firebase features to keep track of online players, synchronize game state across multiple connections, create chat rooms, and match players together for game play.
sessions.speaker: Mark Mandel

sessions.title: Developing Cross-Platform, Native Apps in JavaScript
sessions.description: Overview of methods of developing cross-platform native apps in JavaScript, understanding the differences between cross-platform native and hybrid apps, the different choices and drilling down into one of them to see how it's done in practice.
sessions.speaker: Jason Kneen

sessions.title: The New Mobile Web: Service Worker, Push and App Manifests
sessions.description:
Not just another "Progressive Web Apps" talk.

Compared to native apps, mobile websites have historically been at a disadvantage: no installation, no push notifications, and they only work when you're online.

This year, that changed.

This session examines how the new Service Worker, Push, and App Manifest specifications fill the gaps between web and native. But this isn't just another "Progressive Web App" talk; instead, we'll dicuss the new APIs individually, emphasizing their flexibility and countering the one-size-fits-all hype.

This talk will cover:

1. How to use Service Workers as a programmable proxy/cache for your website, which allows you to make resources available offline.

2. How to use Push to send notifications to your website's users, even when they don't have your site open.

3. How to use a Web App Manifest to control your site's presentation and installability.

We'll also discuss how, taken together, they allow us to create mobile web experiences that are virtually indistinguishable from native. Or not. How you use these specs really is up to you.
sessions.speaker: Dan Callahan

sessions.title: Using Jenkins for Continuous Cross Platform Mobile Development and Distribution
sessions.description: Ease your team's mobile development, testing and distribution workflow by getting Jenkins to handle (most) all of the tedious bits.
sessions.speaker: Adam Paxton

sessions.title: Practical Performance Tips to Make Your Cross Platform Mobile Apps Faster
sessions.description: Apache Cordova is one of the most popular frameworks for cross-platform mobile development. Web developers can build apps for iOS, Android, and Windows based on the same frameworks they use for the Web by using a shared codebase. However, the methods for improving mobile app performance can be different from those web developers use for web apps. Doris Chen outlines what impacts “native performance” and explains how the startup time, as well as the overhead of resume, memory, communication, and the Web, can all contribute to the performance of Cordova apps. To build Cordova apps that perform well, it’s important to understand how to avoid common pitfalls and how to use the technologies in the most efficient ways. Doris introduces tools for performance tests and demonstrates how to measure mobile app performance by using diagnostic tools for different platforms. Doris also shares practical tips for building faster Cordova apps by exploring Document Object Model (DOM) complexity, animation techniques, and memory management.
sessions.speaker: Dr. Doris Chen

sessions.title: ReactNative - Under the hood
sessions.description: ReactNative is a way to create native applications for iOS, Android and Windows devices in JavaScript. In this session, we will look under the covers at the technology that enables ReactNative to drive native user interface components. We will look at a typical developer workflow and the way ReactNative is tied to developer tools. We will round it off with ways to deliver updates to your app without needing to submit updates to the app store.
sessions.speaker: Parashuram

sessions.title: Testing Android Apps with Software Robots
sessions.description: Software robots like monkey provide a quick way to validate your application. With robots on new cloud testing services, it is easier than ever to get started testing your app without even having written any tests. In this talk, I will introduce a few tools from both academia and industry, and then cover the basics of how these tools work. You will learn about the strengths and limitations these tools and how to use them effectively to maximize code coverage and catching failures.
sessions.speaker: Shauvik Roy Choudhary

sessions.title: Advanced Android: Fragments & Services
sessions.description:
Topics in this session will include an in-depth discussion of fragments, as well as services, notifications, and the action bar.

Fragments are fundamental to Android applications, but their implementation can get complicated. We'll look at simple ones, like the preferences fragment, then move to dialogs, and finally a complete summary/detail flow.
sessions.speaker: Ken Kousen

sessions.title: Gradle Recipes for Android
sessions.description:
Android applications no longer use Ant or IDE builds. The new build mechanism is based on Gradle, the popular build tool from the Groovy ecosystem. This talk will introduce Gradle to Android developers and show how easy it is to integrate into Android projects.

The latest version of the Android Studio IDE will be used to develop applications. Topics will include using the Android plugin for Gradle, adding dependencies and alternate repositories, creating custom tasks, implementing both unit and integration tests, using alternative build types, product flavors and variants, and more.
sessions.speaker: Ken Kousen

sessions.title: Data Persistence Essentials
sessions.description: We store a lot of data in our apps, for example, a user’s name and email, a list of friends, to sports scores, just to name a few. The variety of ways to perform this essential task can be overwhelming. In this talk, we will cover the primary forms of data persistence, including best practices.
sessions.speaker: David Hope

sessions.title: What’s new in Android!
sessions.description: Android N, now known as Nougat, was announced this past spring at Google IO 2016.  Drop in to hear a rundown of all the new and exciting features that you as a developer can take advantage of in the new Nougat release.  From the new split window feature to Java 8 feature support, there is some exciting topics to cover.  We will also cover the latest in build tools: Android Studio, Jack and Jill, and Gradle plugins.
sessions.speaker: Douglas Knudsen

sessions.title: Activities in the Wild: Exploring the Android Activity Lifecycle
sessions.description: To Android users, your Activity object is your app.  Take a journey with me to experience what happens to your Activity’s state and view at runtime in relation to what the user (and the operating system itself) is doing.  We will discuss considerations you should make based on this knowledge when designing and building your app.  You will walk away from this talk with a strong understanding of the most fundamental piece of Android applications.
sessions.speaker: Kristin Marsicano

sessions.title: Data Binding
sessions.description: I, too, was skeptical about the idea of data binding in Android development. Would it work? Would it be buggy? Are there any benefits? But now I'm a believer, so let's dive into the pros (and cons) of completely structuring an application around Data Binding.
sessions.speaker: Matthew Compton

sessions.title: Android Development For Arduino 101
sessions.description: The Internet of Things (IoT) and the Quantified Self are the two most significant trends in mobile technology. Knowing how to develop software that interfaces with hardware via a mobile device is a skill every mobile developer should possess. Fortunately, many open source hardware solutions exist such as Arduino, Raspberry PI, RedBoard and a few others, which provides developers an opportunity to cultivate a thorough understanding of electronics and learn how to integrate them using software. This discussion will focus on Arduino since it is the most prominent of these solutions.
sessions.speaker: Bryan Jones Richardson

sessions.title: Communicating with Android Devices
sessions.description: Android apps need to be notified of server side events as well as update the server with their state.  This talk will survey several options as well as go into detail for push using Google’s Firebase Cloud Messaging.
sessions.speaker: Summers Pittman

sessions.title: Kotlin for the Busy Android Developer
sessions.description: Android has been the most widely installed mobile operating system in the world since 2013. It’s an awesome platform and its open source code, which can be used on various different devices, has made it a popular choice for many projects and applications. That said, for developers, Android does have one Achilles heel: Java. The release of Kotlin 1.0 offers a compelling alternative. But, it is a good idea to use it? Let’s take a tour of Kotlin with code samples, cat pictures, and a little bit of live coding. Learn how to put your codebase on a diet and improve its readability by converting your existing classes to Kotlin. See how you can improve your code quality by using the built-in null safety, and how to make unit testing more pleasurable by using the Spek framework. Along the way, we’ll share tips and tricks for using Kotlin in production apps. By the end of this talk you’ll have enough knowledge to confidently start to use Kotlin in your Android projects.
sessions.speaker: Lance Gleason

sessions.title: Let's talk about R.B.A.C.: Handling authorization in NodeJS
sessions.description: Although many of us have used Passport to handle authentication and to a lesser extent authorization, how can we perform more fine grained controls over our features in our application? In this talk we'll discuss some ideas around RBAC and how we can use some of the built-in features of Express to handle these types of authorizations.
sessions.speaker: Josh Backfield

sessions.title: Introduction to Office Graph with Node.js
sessions.description: Overview of using Office Graph API with Node.js to access and manipulate Office 365 data
sessions.speaker: Kristin Ottofy

sessions.title: You Too Can Build a Bot: Programming Bots in Node.JS For Beginners
sessions.description: From Google to Disney, Slack and Facebook, enterprise and consumer, conversational bot interfaces are a hot new trend for 2016. You may think that bots are difficult to program, but with knowledge of Node.JS, they're a lot simpler than you think. Come and learn how to build your first bot.
sessions.speaker: Anthony Jesmok

sessions.title: Creating Robust Cloud Services using Node.js
sessions.description: Cloud services enable mobile apps to have many modern features, such as user accounts, profiles, authentication, and persistent data. This lecture will discuss how to create a scalable infrastructure that provides platform-agnostic REST-based services and how to connect them to iOS applications. Server-side frameworks and libraries include Node.js, Express, MongoDB, Passport, and Composable-Middlewares. We will show the end-to-end solution by building an iOS app, using Swift and Alamofire.
sessions.speaker: Stephen Schwahn

sessions.title: I have a NoSQL toaster
sessions.description: NoSQL is a catch-all term that covers a lot of different types of data storage. Is it really helpful to group them together by one thing they don't have? Think about it like this: my toaster is as much NoSQL as any database! So, how can we make more sense of this new breed of database management systems?
sessions.speaker: Matthew Groves

sessions.title: You Don't Know Node
sessions.description: Node.js is quickly capturing the programming world not just in web, but in IoT, drones, robots and embedded systems. This talk dives deep into the core mechanisms of the Node.js platform and some of its most interesting features. We will brush-up on the core concept which enables the non-blocking I/O. We will discuss streams and buffers, and/or effective ways to work with data. Then we'll have a crash course about event emitters. We will level up our knowledge on how to fork like a pro. We will also discuss AsyncWrap, Domain and uncaughtException. We will also dive into to the core and you'll learn writing your own C++ addons. If you are a geek like most of us, then you’d appreciate this presentation. You’ll become more confident in the internals of Node.js and understand how certain things work.
sessions.speaker: Azat Mardan

sessions.title: Why Node.js is Ready for Enterprise
sessions.description: Node.js and JavaScript are increasing its presence in enterprise software engineering and this is why Node is ready for its prime time in enterprise.
sessions.speaker: Azat Mardan

sessions.title: Horizontally Scaling Node.js and WebSockets
sessions.description: Underneath every breakout website or app is a horizontally scaling back-end, but how do we get from a single process Node.js server to a highly-available, auto-scaling system? In this talk, we’ll take a high level look at a full production stack before getting our hands dirty with the secret sauce: Node.js, WebSockets and Redis. Through a live coding demo, you’ll learn how to take a single-server app and scale it infinitely. Walk away with a better conceptual understanding of high-scale web systems and practical tools to start implementing these techniques in your own projects today.
sessions.speaker: James Simpson

sessions.title: Introduction to LoopBack
sessions.description: An introduction to building APIs with the open-source framework, LoopBack. Some familiarity with APIs and Node.js in general is suggested.
sessions.speaker: Raymond Camden

sessions.title: Introduction to npm as a Build Tool
sessions.description: Grunt and Gulp are the heavyweights in the JavaScript build tool landscape. These tools can automate almost anything you find yourself doing repeatedly in a project, from minifying and concatenating source files, to running tests or compiling code. But the question is, do you need them? npm’s script directive can do everything that these build tools can, more succinctly, more elegantly, with less package dependencies and less maintenance overhead. In this session I will discuss what npm is capable of as a build tool.
sessions.speaker: Jennifer Bland

sessions.title: Developing IOT and Smart Devices at Scale with the Cloud
sessions.description: This session will cover how to develop secure, scalable, IoT cross-device solutions with Node.js IoT frameworks like Johnny Five as well as, building data backend for your IoT and Smart Devices with the Cloud.
sessions.speaker: Tara Walker

sessions.title: IOS in the Enterprise: App distribution and other advanced topics
sessions.description: The enterprise environment is different than a commercial or consumer facing development effort. In this intermediate level workshop workshop, we'll cover these topics and take a deep dive into the challenges facing enterprise app developers: Monitoring the app in the field, Enterprise UX concerns, Privacy concerns, APIs and capabilities you'll only use in the enterprise, Enterprise deployment walled garden, Advanced problem solving for application design and performance
sessions.speaker: Carol Shepherd

sessions.title: AngularJS 2 and TypeScript Workshop
sessions.description:
SKILL LEVEL: INTERMEDIATE
PREREQUISITES: Working knowledge of JavaScript.
TICKET MUST BE PURCHASED SPECIFICALLY FOR THIS WORKSHOP IN ADDITION TO MAIN CONFERENCE TICKET.

This is a hands-on workshop, you will need your laptop. Workshop instructions will be sent before the event.

AngularJS is the incredibly popular framework for building single-page web applications. Version 2.0 is a major leap from the 1.x version designed to address shortcomings in the original 5+ year old framework and to embrace modern browsers and language features. It is being written using TypeScript, a superset of JavaScript that allows you to build code using next generation features and compile it to JavaScript that will run on current browsers. In this session Jeremy Likness goes hands-on to show you how to set up your environment and build your first application while teaching you about the advantages of the framework and language based on his years of in-the-field experience architecting enterprise Angular applications.
sessions.speaker: Jeremy Likness

sessions.title: Practically functional programming
sessions.description: Functional programming is all the rage these days, but our codebases, libraries, and built-in methods are predominately Object-Oriented. Using OO syntax with functional constructs, we can write in a style compatible with either paradigm and enjoy the benefits of both.
sessions.speaker: Brian Lonsdorf

sessions.title: ES6 (and beyond) Workshop
sessions.description: The EcmaScript standard is now on a yearly release cycle. With ES6 complete and ES2016 ratified, we have a ton of awesome new features to use in our daily software development. In this training, we'll learn about the features you're likely to use and benefit from on a day-to-day basis. In the afternoon, we'll take an existing application and update it to leverage these features using with modern tools like Babel. My goal is that after this training, you'll be able to go back to your projects and add these tools so you can write ES.next code today.
sessions.speaker: Kent C. Dodds

sessions.title: Up and Running with Ionic v2
sessions.description: In this workshop you will be introduced to the Ionic v2 framework, a powerful hybrid mobile solution. Built atop of Angular 2 and Apache Cordova, this framework gives developers an incredibly powerful set of mobile components to create app store-ready apps.
sessions.speaker: Mike Hartington

sessions.title: Advanced JavaScript: Foundations
sessions.description: In this one-day intensive course, we will dive deep into core mechanisms of the JS language, probably more than you ever have before. Our goal is to not merely understand what these things do, but how and why. We will cover: • nested lexical scope • hoisting • closures • modules • 'this' keyword • common oo patterns • object prototypes • delegation vs inheritance
sessions.speaker: getify

sessions.title: Animating the User Interface: Designing for Motion
sessions.description: From transitions to loaders, user interfaces are coming alive with motion like we've never seen before. Animation, or “motion design,” has become an essential part of the designer’s toolkit for expressing fundamental interaction design principles. In this workshop, the instructor will show how the aims of interaction design are fulfilled through animation and will discuss what to consider when using animation in your own designs. Through discussion and hands-on implementation, attendees will learn to design and prototype animation using tools like Keynote, Principle, Pixate, or Invision.
sessions.speaker: Angie Terrell

sessions.title: Workshop: Modern Applications with Aurelia
sessions.description: Aurelia is a next generation JavaScript client framework for mobile, desktop and web. It's the most standards-compliant, highly performing and simplest technology of its kind today. In this course you'll have an opportunity to learn directly from Aurelia's architect and project lead, Rob Eisenberg. He'll teach you how to create modern web applications using an MVVM approach with Aurelia. You also will learn how to extend HTML with custom elements and attributes, how to handle client-side routing and even cover best practices in project organization, maintenance and deployment.
sessions.speaker: Rob Eisenberg

sessions.title: React.js Hands-on workshop
sessions.description:
SKILL LEVEL: INTERMEDIATE 
PREREQUISITES: Working knowledge of JavaScript. 
TICKET MUST BE PURCHASED SPECIFICALLY FOR THIS WORKSHOP IN ADDITION TO MAIN CONFERENCE TICKET.

React.js is a view library from Facecbook for building performant user-interfaces in JavaScript. In this session, we'll explore React.js and understand why it's a great step forward for building complex UI's that run fast. We'll code up an example web application using React.js and step through the basics of using the library while discussing concepts like the virtual DOM and components.

This is a HAND-ON WORKSHOP, INTRODUCTORY LEVEL. Please come with a laptop, and if possible, with the software needed pre-installed (Instructions below). We'll cover these topics - both in code and in discussion format, and do as many as we can in the time alloted:

React components
Lifecycle
Properties
State
Using React-Bootstrap components
Signaling & Messaging between Component
Handling Events
All coding done in ES6 style
Modern React application structure, setup, and build
Writing tests
React Router
Discussion of Flux architecture
REST/Network ops within React
React architecture
Component composition
Discussion of Redux and Functional Web Architecture (time permitting!)
sessions.speaker: Andrew Smith

sessions.title: Thinking in Swift for iOS
sessions.description: This fast-paced workshop shows you how to take advantage of Swift features to write more robust code that is easier to reason about. We’ll spend a good part of the day looking at functional programming and playing with map, filter, reduce, and flatmap but we will also create instances of classes, structs, and enums. We’ll explore how your iOS app architecture may change when you embrace idiomatic Swift.
sessions.speaker: Daniel Steinberg

sessions.title: A Journey in Web VR
sessions.description: This talk discusses the challenges around developing a Web VR project that has a strong emphasis on accessibility and DIY.
sessions.speaker: Dee Del Rosario

sessions.title: Thinking Differently About Web Performance
sessions.description: Performance is vital to success on the web, but it is often thought of in terms of load time rather than what happens when a user actually starts using your web app. In this talk, we’ll take an in-depth look into the tools and techniques you can use from right within your browser to help your web app match its native counterparts. We’ll walk through several live demos of real-world performance issues and their solutions, from CPU bottlenecks to page crashing memory leaks. You’ll walk away better understanding the tools at your disposal and how to apply those to up the game of your current or upcoming projects.
sessions.speaker: James Simpson

sessions.title: Why poor UX and performance are bouncing your website visitors, and what to do about it.
sessions.description:
Everyone knows fast sites provide a better UX and have happy users which generate more revenue. But since there are literally hundreds of issues that could be slowing down your pages, How do you figure out (and fix) the ones that are hurting your business most?

Using data from the Top IR200 retail sites, Billy will show attendees how to:

-Gather historical user data via RUM
-Correlate load times with conversions
-Determine which pages in your site are most impacting your business goals.
-Show the top 10 issues that create the biggest bounce rates on the top retail sites on the web.

No doubt you’ve encountered scores of lists outlining the top performance issues faced by sites. Unlike those lists, this list is grounded in a study of revenue/business impact. Using this approach, you can focus on fixing the performance defects that are hurting you most on the pages that matter the most.
sessions.speaker: Billy Hoffman

sessions.title: Developing Web Applications: Standards, Best Practices and Tools
sessions.description: Web developers have a range of tools and choices available to create solutions for the continuum of browsers and devices. Responsive web design, microservices, security, HTML5 video, HTTP/2, containers, and web performance are some of the pertinent topics when developing web applications. This session will cover web industry standards, best practices, and frameworks related to these and other emerging web technologies.
sessions.speaker: Ian Moraes

sessions.title: Perf Session hold (WH)
sessions.description: Perf Session hold (WH)
sessions.speaker: Pratik Patel

sessions.title: Creating meaningful HTML and CSS
sessions.description: Creating meaningful HTML and CSS : The BEM way!
sessions.speaker: Rachita Joshi

sessions.title: Web-based Virtual Reality
sessions.description: Virtual reality (VR) is an amazing medium that helps create immersive stories for nearly any industry, from journalism to manufacturing to gaming.  Virtual reality hardware systems like Google Cardboard, Oculus Rift, Samsung Gear and others are starting to making VR a household name.  On the software side, most of the activity is confined to native applications, but the web can bring major advantages to VR that only increase the accessibility of this platform, including experiencing VR without downloading and installing apps and allowing seamless connections from one experience to another via hyperlinks.  This session will examine the technologies bringing VR to the web including Google’s VR view & VR shell, Mozilla VR and  WebVR, a vendor--vendor-independent web standards for VR.
sessions.speaker: Erica Stanley

sessions.title: Whirlwind Tour of HTML5
sessions.description: HTML and JavaScript have come a long way since the dark days of IE's domination of the browser market. In this talk, Jordan Kasper will introduce you to some of the exciting new features in HTML5 that we can implement right now in our applications! We'll look at capturing the user's camera data, accessing their location, reading the file system, native drag and drop, and even vibrating their phone! Join us for a session of fun demos and new experiences. Attendees will walk away from this session with some ideas about how to make your web applications even more amazing with these new APIs.
sessions.speaker: Jordan Kasper

sessions.title: Leave No One Behind: Building Accessible Web Applications
sessions.description: Over 50 million adults in the US have a disability, and some of them want to use your web site. Can they? This session will not only help you answer that question, it will help you answer "Yes." Join us as we learn how to build web applications accessible to everyone.
sessions.speaker: Stephen A Thomas

sessions.title: Getting Started with Jekyll for Static Sites
sessions.description: Static sites offer fantastic benefits in things like security and performance. Static site generators have made it easier to build and maintain static sites. Jekyll is the most widely used and, in my opinion, the best overall option for static site development. In this session, we'll cover how to get started with Jekyll to build, customize and maintain a static site.
sessions.speaker: Brian Rinaldi

sessions.title: CSS from the Future
sessions.description:
For years, we’ve relied on preprocessors to simplify CSS development, but the time is coming when we won’t need this anymore. Variables, mixins, mathematic calculations, color manipulation, and nested selectors are all in the official specification, at various stages of development. Nearly every feature provided by SASS and LESS is coming to the browser. Some of it has already arrived. Some of it is even more powerful than the preprocessor you are used to.

In this talk, I’ll show you how all these features work. And I’ll show you how, using the PostCSS processor, you can transpile this future syntax into code you can use today. Come take a glimpse at what the future of CSS holds.
sessions.speaker: Keith J Grant

speakers.name: Jordan Kasper
speakers.bio: Shortly after it arrived at his home in 1993, Jordan began disassembling his first computer - his mother was not happy. She breathed more easily when he moved from hardware into programming. Jordan's experience includes development at startups, agencies, Fortune 100 companies, and universities, as well as numerous open source projects. He has coded in many languages from BASIC to Java to PHP and most recently JavaScript and Node.js. He speaks regularly at (and helps organize) local user groups, conferences large and small, and hackathons. Jordan's primary mission for over 10 years has been to evangelize technology of all sorts and share what he has learned to help others grow. He is currently a front-end engineering instructor with The Iron Yard in Washington, DC. In his down time he enjoys puzzles of all sorts and board games!

speakers.name: Tim Whitacre
speakers.bio: I've been living in ATL for a little over 2 years. I am the director of Front End Engineering at The Iron Yard Atlanta.

speakers.name: Giovanny Gongora
speakers.bio:
I'm Giovanny Gongora, aka Gioyik. I am Porting Developer at Mozilla. Javascriptero since creation of the universe. Time ago translator at Tor Project and Security tester. I enjoy trying new things like Rust and Go, sometimes creating custom languages and working on my own projects.

I give talks about web technologies, open source, net neutrality, programming languages that suck and how cats will control the world in the future.

speakers.name: Nick Larsen
speakers.bio: Nick Larsen is a performance oriented developer for the Stack Overflow data team.  He is a husband, a father and graduate student at GA Tech.

speakers.name: Burk Hufnagel
speakers.bio: Burk is a long-time programmer and software architect, with experience in multiple languages including Java and JavaScript. He’s presented at multiple conferences including DevNexus and JavaOne, and contributed to two of the “97 Things” books published by O’Reilly. He works as a Technical Architect for Daugherty Business Solutions where he's focused on finding ways to deliver better code in less time, teaching others how to do the same thing, and looking for ways to improve his skills and the skills of his team.

speakers.name: Patrick Seda
speakers.bio: Patrick is CTO of Colligo Vox, a Mobile solutions consulting company based out of Atlanta. With over 25 years of professional experience, he orchestrates and implements successful mobile initiatives. Ranging from enterprise behemoth applications to children’s educational games, his focus is delivering bullet-proof, awesomely kickass apps.

speakers.name: Jonathan Martin
speakers.bio: Jonathan is a cheesecake-loving Developer & Instructor at Big Nerd Ranch, where he sheds bikes in Rails or bores students with the “wats” of JavaScript in the Ranch’s immersive front-end bootcamp.

speakers.name: Corinna Cohn
speakers.bio: Corinna Cohn has been creating websites since 1995 and has written web apps for radio stations, research projects, scientific publishing, and business-to-business clients. Over the past several years, Corinna has worked with Backbone, Ember, and Angular to design and write single-page applications. Corinna has written ugly, unmaintainable code but is now working to bring the principles of clean code, unit tests, and high-quality refactoring into the realm of JavaScript web application

speakers.name: Joe Conway
speakers.bio: Joe Conway is the founder and CEO of stable|kernel, an Atlanta-based mobile software company offering end-to-end development services to craft smartly-designed mobile applications that connect brands directly with their users – across tablets, smartphones, desktops, wearables and the Internet of Things. For the past 16 years, Joe has programmed everything from Mac OS X to Android to iOS. As a former instructor and lead developer at Big Nerd Ranch, he fine-tuned his skills and expertise in overall mobile strategy, specializing in iOS Development. The author of iOS Programming: The Big Nerd Ranch Guide, an Amazon best seller, Joe quickly made a name for himself in the mobile space. He has worked with Fortune 500 companies, technology start-ups and government entities to build mobile platforms, enhance existing applications and develop mobile strategies.

speakers.name: Stephen M. Carlson
speakers.bio: Full-stack Software Engineer obsessed with writing high quality, maintainable and extensible code. Agile evangelist, technology leader and entrepreneur.

speakers.name: Josh Teague
speakers.bio: Head of Design at FullStory, previously at Google.

speakers.name: Stephanie Brubaker
speakers.bio: Stephanie Brubaker is a full stack engineer at FullStory, a Customer Success platform that lets companies easily record, replay, search, and analyze each user’s actual experience with their website. With a primary focus on frontend web development, she works closely with the FullStory design team to turn their brilliant designs into high-leverage UIs. Stephanie was previously an engineer at Google, where she worked on the Google Web Toolkit and complex version control systems. She has a CS Masters degree from Georgia Tech and finds soldering fun and relaxing.

speakers.name: Mike Gorgone
speakers.bio: I have 20+ years in the software industry with the last 4 years focused on User Experience Design, collaboratively executing large enterprise-level web initiatives. I enjoy working with teams that, truly create TOGETHER, solutions that best solve the problem at hand. I feel immense pain when I see or use a website with a poor user experience. I want the web to be great and I want my teammates to be great as well and I do everything I can to make them look like Rock Stars.

speakers.name: Jad Joubran
speakers.bio: Very early on, at the age of 19, Jad Joubran founded eTobb. Nowadays, his experience mentoring developers across different channels, and coaching Web Development in Amsterdam, Brussels & Lisbonwith Le Wagon.

speakers.name: Nicole Saidy
speakers.bio: I'm a web designer with a passion for creating beautiful design solutions for the digital world with knowledge in web, mobile, front-end development & more.

speakers.name: Will Jayroe
speakers.bio: Will Jayroe is a multi-disciplinary professional specializing in Solutions Architecture, User Interface and Front-End Technology consulting, User Experience strategy, Visual and Interaction Design.

speakers.name: Josh Marinacci
speakers.bio: Josh is an O’Reilly author, developer advocate, and recovering engineer. He is the technical marketing manager at PubNub. Previously he worked as a developer evangelist at Nokia, Palm / HP, and Sun. He is passionate about user interfaces and education. Josh lives in sunny Eugene, Oregon.

speakers.name: Grant Davies
speakers.bio: Grant Davies, CEO of Bluetube, has an extensive background in technology development with a passion for researching and predicting future technology trends. Before founding Bluetube in 1999, Grant worked for two decades as a developer and architect. Since then, he’s built innovate digital solutions for global 2000, nonprofit and mid-market clients in industries including healthcare, manufacturing, consumer products, arts and entertainment.

speakers.name: Andrew Malek
speakers.bio: Andrew is a UI developer and occasional designer at NCR, focusing on POS (point-of-sale) and clienteling solutions. He has two decades of development experience in languages such as JavaScript, Visual Basic, Python, and C, and will admit to having developed a content management solution with Delphi and Perl if backed into a corner.

speakers.name: Rob Eisenberg
speakers.bio: Rob Eisenberg is a JavaScript expert working out of Tallahassee, FL and he is the CEO of Durandal Inc. Rob got his start with computer programming at the age of nine, when he thoroughly fell in love with his family's new Commodore 64. His fascination with programming started with the Commodore Basic language, then moved to Q Basic and QuickBasic and quickly continued on to C, C++, C# and JavaScript. Rob publishes technical articles regularly at http://eisenbergeffect.bluespire.com and has spoken at regional events and to companies concerning Web  technologies, Agile software practices and UI engineering. He is the creator of the Durandal and Caliburn.Micro frameworks. He’s formerly a member of the Angular 2.0 Core Team at Google, before leaving to return to work on Durandal and it’s next generation platform: Aurelia.

speakers.name: Dylan Schiemann
speakers.bio: Dylan Schiemann is CEO of SitePen and co-founder of the Dojo Toolkit.

speakers.name: Bob Holben
speakers.bio: Bob is an engineer who's career has centered around R&D and manufacturing in both the physical world and the software world.  With experience launching 3 companies, Bob's recent passion has been with JavaScript and Angular.

speakers.name: Pearl Latteier
speakers.bio: Pearl Latteier is a software engineer at Bendyworks in Madison WI. For the past several years, she has focused primarily on building data-intensive JavaScript applications for web and mobile, most recently with React JS and React Native. She is also experienced with server-side technologies including Ruby on Rails, Node, and PHP. Before becoming a software developer, Pearl earned a PhD in from the University of Wisconsin-Madison, where for five years she taught courses in the Department of Communication Arts.

speakers.name: Delicia Brummitt
speakers.bio:
Delicia is a tech generalist that has worked as web designer to DBA, Software Engineer to QA.  With a motto of “Work Smarter not Harder”, she is driven to finding elegant solutions that make life easier. 

Delicia is currently working as a Software Engineer at UPS.

speakers.name: Brian Lonsdorf
speakers.bio: Brian Lonsdorf is functional programmer who uses JavaScript all day at work. Sometimes he is known as that “underscore talk guy” or the author of the Mostly Adequate Guide to Functional Programming. He is a Frontend master™, a panelist on jsair, makes stop motion videos, and writes his own bios.

speakers.name: Chris Morrow
speakers.bio: I'm a Senior UI Developer, currently specializing in Data Visualization at The Weather Company. I constantly seek new coding best practices and workflows. I love to learn and I love to teach. I am thankful for those that helped me learn to code better throughout my career, and I enjoy giving back and helping others. I've used a number of web technologies including JavaScript, NodeJS, AngularJS, KnockoutJS, Aurelia, D3, jQuery, SASS/CSS, HTML, and even Flash, and Flex.

speakers.name: Ben Vinegar
speakers.bio: Ben Vinegar is a software engineer at Sentry, and the co-author of Third-party JavaScript. He lives and works in San Francisco.

speakers.name: Jeremy Likness
speakers.bio: Jeremy is the director of application development and principal architect at iVision, a technology services company that leverages data center, converged infrastructure, engineering support services, delivery assurance, and application development practices to engineer the future for clients, today. Jeremy wrote his first program in 1982, was recognized in the "who's who in Quake" list for programming the first implementation of "Midnight Capture the Flag" in Quake C and has been developing enterprise applications for 20 years. For the past 15 years he has specialized in web-based delivery of line of business applications. Jeremy is the author of four technology books, a six year Microsoft MVP for Windows Platform Development, a Telerik Kendo UI Developer Expert, and speaks and writes regularly on web-based topics such as AngularJS. Jeremy is vegan and spends most of his free time running, hiking and camping with his family, watching retro science fiction movies with his daughter and playing 9-ball and one pocket.

speakers.name: Peter Pavlovich
speakers.bio:
Peter is the Chief Architect at Dispatch Technologies, developers of the most powerful on-demand services platform and is based in Boston, MA.

Before joining Dispatch, Peter was the Principal Architect for EnerNOC Labs, a dedicated R&D group within EnerNOC, a Global provider of Demand Response and Energy Inteligence software located in Boston, MA. 
Prior to EnerNOC, Peter was a Principal Cloud Engineer with Kronos Incorporated, a global provider of on-premise and cloud-based workforce management solutions. Before Kronos, Peter held the position of Technical Director with Brokat Technologies, a global provider of mobile payment solutions. Prior to that, Peter was a Sr. Architect with GemStone Systems, providing distributed, enterprise-ready data grid and object persistence solutions and J2EE application server technologies.

speakers.name: Minko Gechev
speakers.bio: Minko is a functional time-traveler and freelance software engineer with a passion for open source. He loves to experiment with theoretical concepts and apply them in practice. Minko teaches, speaks and writes about JavaScript and Angular. Some of the projects he works on are “Switching to Angular 2”, codelyzer, angular2-style-guide and many others. Currently changing education with Learn Capital.

speakers.name: Shawn Johnson
speakers.bio: Lover of all things mobile. Founding Hero @ Mobile App Hero, Mobile Instructor @ Gerneral Assembly.

speakers.name: Bradford Dillon
